HL7 Standard.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide (IG) focuses on representing Occupational Data for Health (ODH) using FHIR resources, primarily Observation. It's designed to be integrated into broader IGs and doesn't utilize HL7 v2, v3, or CDA. While it doesn't explicitly mention cross-paradigm integration, its design for inclusion in other IGs suggests a degree of interoperability with other HL7 standards.

Geographic Scope.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide focuses on Occupational Data for Health (ODH) and is explicitly designed for the US Realm, as indicated by its development under the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH), a US agency. It also references US-specific value sets. While it acknowledges international needs and uses some international concepts, the primary governance and design are centered around US requirements.

Domain Focus.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide (IG) focuses on standardizing the representation and exchange of Occupational Data for Health (ODH). It primarily addresses the clinical domain by enabling the capture of work-related information to inform patient care and diagnosis. It also significantly supports public health by providing structured data for analyzing work-related health trends and facilitating reporting. While not designed for billing, it touches upon administrative aspects by capturing employer information. The IG emphasizes structured data representation using FHIR profiles and value sets, with a focus on clinical and public health use cases.

Implementers.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide (IG) focuses on standardizing the representation and exchange of Occupational Data for Health (ODH). It's primarily designed for EHR systems to capture and share structured work information, which is crucial for clinical care, population health analysis, and public health reporting. While EHRs are the core systems, public health systems and research platforms will also play significant roles in utilizing this data. Clinical decision support systems will leverage this information to provide better care, and PHR systems may surface some of this data to patients. Payer systems are explicitly excluded from the scope of this IG.

Users & Stakeholders.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide (IG) focuses on standardizing the representation and exchange of occupational data for health (ODH). Its primary users are clinical care teams and public health agencies, who leverage this data for patient care, population health monitoring, and reporting. Research organizations also play a significant role in utilizing this data for studies. While government agencies have a defined role in oversight and regulation, the IG is not designed for billing or administrative purposes, thus limiting the involvement of payers and healthcare administrators. Patients and caregivers have minimal direct interaction with the IG.
